      • formatNumberAddCommas

        public static java.lang.String formatNumberAddCommas(long number)
        Simple formatter to add in commas for formatting. Obtained from: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3672731/how-can-i-format-a-string-number-to-have-commas-and-round
        Parameters:
        number - number to round. If unparseable, will return number
        Returns:
        Formatted String. IE, 44234 would return as 44,234

      • formatNumberAddCommas

        public static java.lang.String formatNumberAddCommas(double number)
        Simple formatter to add in commas for formatting. Obtained from: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3672731/how-can-i-format-a-string-number-to-have-commas-and-round
        Parameters:
        number - number to round. If unparseable, will return number
        Returns:
        Formatted String. IE, 44234 would return as 44,234

      • convertDoubleToStringAddZero

        public static java.lang.String convertDoubleToStringAddZero(double value,
                                                            java.lang.Boolean addDollarSign)
        This used when a double ends in 0 (IE 100.0) and you want to remove the significant figures after the decimal point (assuming they end in zero)
        Parameters:
        value - The double to convert
        addDollarSign - boolean, if null passed, nothing, if true passed, will add a $ to the beginning
        Returns:
        A String, formatted correctly. Will look like this: 104.44 or $99. if the last 2 are 00, it will remove the significant figures after the decimal as well as the decimal itself

      • convertDoubleToStringAddZeroNoRemove

        public static java.lang.String convertDoubleToStringAddZeroNoRemove(double value,
                                                                    java.lang.Boolean addDollarSign)
        This used when a double ends in 0 (IE 100.0) and you want 2 decimal places instead (IE 100.00)
        Parameters:
        value - The double to convert
        addDollarSign - boolean, if null passed, nothing, if true passed, will add a $ to the begining
        Returns:
        A String, formatted correctly. Will look like this: 104.44 or $99.40

        Get a random number between a min and max
        Parameters:

        max - higher end max
